Entry.1:
Up at 7 a.m. and had breakfast with Harold Smith, Howell and G. Hughes. Then met M. Peters and he took us down to the mine at Marcinelle Nord near which there is an ancient Roman tumulus. At the bureaux of the mine we were presented to the chief Engineer who agreed to take us down. Went into cubicles and changed all clothes dressing in ones supplied by them. Rough shirts dungarees and neckerchief. To crown all a smart skull cap and a leather helmet not unlike our steel helmets in shape. Then drew miners safety lamps and went to the pithead. Here girls in breeches were slaving pulling trucks out of the cages and running them along tracks. For 10 hours daily (or 12) they work thus and get a wage of 3/10. Crouched

 

Marcinelle

11/3/19

up in the cage we descended the mine going down over a kilometre in depth. The cage went fairly fast and the first levels were wet and dripping. Reached the bottom at last and walked along the galleries. The increased atmospheric pressure caused a slight pain in the ears. The roof of the gallery revetted and struts had given in many places under the pressure. On small rails trucks were being hauled by ponies. The only light was from our lamps. After a long walk we found the heat so intense as to be uncomfortable and we came at last to the coal faces. The air full of dust and the miners crouched up picking almost naked and holding their lamps between their teeth one boy nearly nude buried waist deep in coal shovelling hard.

 

Marcinelle

11/3/19

Sweating black faces – an awful existence. Long hours & poor wages are causing intense dissatisfaction and unless demands are granted a revolution is promised after our Army is pulled out. Coming up to surface again discomfort to ears was again felt. Visited the engines – all electric and all made in Charleroi. All black we had a group photograph taken and then a good bath and glass of beer prior to saying au revoir. Spring is here. Today on the trees is the first green blush of buds. Walked up the street this afternoon and had a shave. The present strength of the Brigade is such that amalgamation into one big battalion is now the next pressing consideration. Evening went round to Jack’s billet and find him on the mend.

 

Marcinelle

12/3/19

A mild springlike but dull day. To the 22nd and fixed up divers things and then round to see General Robertson at D.H.Q. where we made preliminary arrangements for the final winding up of the Brigade. Put in the morning completing the arrangements. G. Bailey having done us in the eye for 1000 francs I arranged to bring him to book at a Court of Inquiry. The afternoon was showery. Visited Charleroi & then trammed to Mont-sur-Marchienne where the 2nd beat 4th Div at football. Dined at Bde.H.Q and then did a round of the town where Mme Germaine was taking a walk. Called for some photographs and then went to Thewlis billet and then to the Officer’s Mess where I had a good talk to Frenyer and others. Tonight V.N. Moore was running a dance.

 

Marcinelle

13/3/19

Col. G. Murphy presided at Court of Inquiry today re 1000 francs that Bailey cannot account for. Round at the 22nd there was nothing fresh doing. Made preliminary arrangements for commencing Orderly Room & for 6th Bde Battn tomorrow. After lunch went up round the streets of Charleroi and saw a rather amusing auction sale of army horses conducted all in French by an aged auctioneer. The sun shining today and all the trees bursting into bud – the very feel of Spring is in the air. It has indeed been a mild winter compared with those we experienced in the past. Spent the evening chez Mme Marcelle Bertrand and old Mme Crochelet was there – quelle affaire!

 

Marcinelle

14/3/19

At 9.30 addressed about 30 reinforcements on their duty to their Battalion and upholding its dignity and then wandered round to the Echo office. Colonel Geo. Murphy C.M.G, D.S.O was with us to lunch and afterwards came up to the University de Travail to see the finals for the Boxing Championship of the Corps. There were some good fights. At its conclusion General Rawlinson made a good quiet speech to the troops and said he was prepared to say publicly that the Australian Corps was the very best in the British Army. This naturally pleased the troops. At mess tonight we drank the health of the 6th Brigade as from tonight it ceases to exist after 4 years active service. Colonel Linton its first Brig. – myself the last. What changes. Tomorrow the 2nd Dvn Inf Group commences & the

is Adjutant. Yarned with Major Davis and mooned about doing nothing or less than that. In the afternoon corrected a good deal of Gormans History and then met Major Davis and went up to the Museum Anatomique up the town. These waxworks are ghastly & gruesome physiological show of sexual matters and the lifelike representation of maladies nearly make one sick. In Australia such a thing would not be allowed to exist for half an hour. One loses perspective here and it will be hard for us to get once more used to the strait laced ideas of Australia. Dined at the 22nd mess and afterwards took wine with Monsieur Cornil & went to bed at 11 pm.

 

Marcinelle
Entry.6: Sunday. Did a little work and then met General Robertson in the Place. Yarned with for a while corrected some history and then dined at D.H.Q very well with the G. afterwards accompanying him to Thuinno where we saw horseracing and gambling. Great crowds bookmakers and canteens. A pleasant run back in the car and then had afternoon tea with the General before going to mess where Greenaway and Harrison entertained me with Weisbaden & Rhine experiences. To the Varieties theatre and saw a very good representation of Faust. The filthy public urination here is disgusting. In the intervals out in the street long rows of women fouling the walls in all shaded places and men doing the same.
Entry.7:
Marcinelle

Took a walk round the cooks this morning and visited the Echo office and other odd places until lunch time. Dr Daniel then went over me for life assurance – a rather long operation after which we went up the town together and had some afternoon tea. Read and wrote until mess and then afterwards went to Dr Mathys to spend the evening. They seem truly a happy couple and we drank wine and coffee and ate biscuits & a tart. Here in conversation we discuss all sorts of topics that otherwise would be absolutely forbidden. They are fine openhearted folk full of hospitality and cannot be too kind. Gorman and myself have asked them to come with us to the Opera next Sunday evening.
Entry.8:
Marcinelle

The usual morning round except that I met little Les and inspected all his Lewis guns. An impressive sight this morning was the funeral of a Belgian soldier killed in 1914 & whose exhumed body was now being buried. First came our firing party with arms reversed followed by band playing Dead March in Saul and then altarboys crucifix and priests. The coffin was carried by Belgian soldiers and the came relatives and spectators. Church bell tolling all the time. After went up the town to try and learn dancing and made rough weather of a waltz. From there went to the Berlitz school and put in an hour with a detestable Belgian chap who teaches there. We mess nowadays at 5.30 which seems early and 7 pm finds it still light. Went and teased Little Les.
Entry.9:
Marcinelle

Absolutely damall to do. Went round and saw General Martin about quotas and other things and then wrote and read till lunch. After lunch had a bath at Charleroi station and then went up the town and met Tommy Roberts. Messed and then took a Berlitz lesson and went round and saw Bertrand.
Entry.10:
Attended a lecture by one sharp Victorian Immigration Expert in London and then went and saw General Martin about some odd matters. The afternoon read wrote and went up the street after mess taking a Berlitz lesson. The wooden sabots are in universal use here and are clumsy – the average price appears about 4 francs. Dancing is a hobby

 with the troops now.
Entry.11:
Marcinelle

The usual round of odd jobs done during the morning and after lunch went up the town with Dr Daniel to take tea or rather chocolate and cakes at a pastry shop where the waitress and a demoiselle sitting in a corner were evidently in league at the oldest profession in the world. Had mess and then tore away to have a dancing lesson with a little Belgian teacher who must be sick to death of clumsy people. Then returning to my billet found any amount of papers for signing. Spent the rest of the evening talking to Beith and his French friends (Belgians) – kind hospitable people. There are said to be many of our chaps marrying Belgian girls but I have only signed one lot of papers. 

 

22/3/19

Marcinelle

Orders arriving for Davis to leave for England I took over the 22’s again tried a case at Orderly Room and put in a fairly busy morning. Lunched and with Gorman Scales & Selleck found Major Charlton A.T.C good enough to take us in his car out to see the 1st beat the
Entry.12: Division at Chatelet. A splendid ground and a good day out. The first Divn proved altogether too good. Motored home in quick time and dined fixed up some papers and went to the pictures. Today we hear of all leave stopped again on account of English strikes and I am sorry all the more because I hear talk of the men getting rather dissatisfied and citing the Canadians as an instance where force brought good results. The necessity for a finger on the pulse of the men becomes a need.
Entry.13:
Marcinelle

Church parade after which an Archdeacon from Lincoln gave a lecture on Industrial Unrest. Had the pleasure of rousing Gorman up because this parade was late. A lovely Spring day today. Took a promenade after lunch and after evening mess visited the town. Quiet.
Entry.14: Snowing all the morning and raining hard all the afternoon. Tried a couple of cases at Orderly Room and was reasonably busy up until lunch time. After lunch read and wrote before going up the town. Bought a guide book to the Rhine and another to Switzerland and was home at 5.30 for mess.
Entry.15:
Marcinelle

Snowing when I woke up with a leaden head and a violent cold in it. Dies irae! Fairly busy on routine till noon and afterwards about all the battalion was fooled up over a band concert which made us all very annoyed. Bad staff work. After evening mess I roused up the officers about language. Stayed in all the evening. Rotten.
Entry.16: A fairly busy day. Dealt with many matters during the morning – a range from fining a chap 10/- for not wearing colours to dealing with cinemas and other things. Afternoon went up to the E.F.C Officers club and then had afternoon tea at our mess. Word for 18 subalterns to leave the Bde for home. Picked them and then found several not so keen to go – cherchez les femmes. Dined with Dr Mathys.
Entry.17:
Marcinelle

Some snow fell this morning. I found myself very busy until 11.30 – holding orderly room and attending to matters of routine. The Higher Command leaves well alone here and visits from the G.O.C are rare. Afternoon said farewell to a few officers leaving for Australia and had a dancing lesson which broke me up. Stayed home correcting history.
Entry.18: Another cold and snowy day. Spent a busy morning mostly in argument with Selleck about the next draft. Afternoon read a while and then went up the town to go and buy a Petit Parisien and then aimlessly come back. Dr Milleu came to evening mess and said he goes home soon. In the evening I went back to the Cinema and saw some good pictures.
Entry.19:
Marcinelle

Woke up to find the world in white. Rooves and trees weighted with snow and large heavy flakes drifting down. Spent a fairly busy morning on routine odds and ends and at lunch had some things of interest to discuss with a Y.M.C.A lecturer. Smythe came in for a talk after lunch and then I went round to DHQ and had a long talk with General Robertson fixing up a number of things. While there Major General Tivey came in as Robertson goes to England. We all had afternoon tea together and talked a good deal about military life in Australia. After evening mess took a walk up the town and had a good look round. Snow on the ground and in the air sent me to bed ravenously hungry.
Entry.20:
Marcinelle

Sunday and cold and snowy in the morning. Kept fairly busy till 11, then had a few words to the 21st Band before they left and then had a talk to General Martin on the subject of 1916 men. I put the case very strongly and after lunch also wrote him a note. Our draft figures are the ridiculously small 296! There were several heavy snow storms before evening and the place looked remarkably beautiful so deeply covered with the flakes. Took a walk around the streets after dark. Lots of people abroad on Sunday you would hardly recognise in the smart fashionably dressed people - especially the women the slatterns of week days. To my billet about 9 and wrote before going to sleep.
Entry.21:
Marcinelle

The snow still lies about fairly thick. At my billet two lambs have put in an appearance and the children are in high delight. Saw General Martin again this morning and then kept extremely busy right up until noon and most of the afternoon too. Went to the Green Diamonds for the evening. Their “girl" is good. Picked next draft to go. The people here are very scrupulous about locking all doors at night.
Entry.22: Attended a conference at Group H.Q. where General Martin discoursed in platitudes and nothing very much eventuated except that I may get away by 7 May and that it is officially estimated that all Australians will have gone by 20 May. Afternoon interviewed different people and in the evening had a long walk around Charleroi.
Entry.23:
Marcinelle

Today was fine and ideally Springlike. Fairly busy all the morning doing the usual things until 10.30 when a Miss Baxter, an Australienne, arrived to give the troops a lecture or rather a talk about Australia. She was very interesting and afterwards came over to the mess and had a cup of tea. Afternoon went up to the Charleroi Railway Station and had a hot bath. This place has some remarkable wall paintings over which much trouble has been taken – one very obscene and so elaborate as to show a deliberately low mentality. Had afternoon mess and after went down to Jack’s billet to find him well and much invigorated by his trip to Germany. Cold and frosty tonight.
Entry.24:
Marcinelle

Visited the Printing office this morning and then tried a case at Orderly Room – Lennon a real criminal. Went round and had a talk with General Martin for a while. After lunch went up round Charleroi High Town and, being a fine Springlike day, the walk was very enjoyable. Returned across the canal bridge pausing to see how the locks are worked – a rapid manner they have here. At 5 p.m. went to a dinner of the 24th Battalion to their departing draft. It was very successful and I made a short speech to the men. Afterwards one of the Euroa Liddells came up and had a talk. Tonight is beautifully calm and mild and the green on the trees and the feel in the air proclaim that Spring is here.
Entry.25:
Marcinelle

Usual round of routine and a visit to the “Echo" Printing office. Dealt with several matters which included no less a circumstance than the loss of 500 fr from Cinema profits by the Staff Capt. Ordered that he pay it. Afternoon had a visit from one of the Liddells and then saw various people and wrote until 5 pm when I walked down to the Maison du Peuple where the 22nd had a jolly good dinner to their departing draft a show which went off in fine style, I made a fairly long speech on the deeds of the 22nd and the 5th Bde concert party added to the programme. After 8 o’c Jack joined me at my billet and Mme Cornil played operatic tunes and others. Monsieur produced choice Burgoyne.
Entry.26:
Marcinelle

A delightful day. Completion of arrangements for our departing draft filled in the morning & I also paid a visit to General Martin regarding Brevet rank in the C.M.F. A short walk up to Charleroi after lunch. In the square there were many market booths erected and the people were crying their wares & evidently doing good business. At 5 pm went to the 23rd dinner and arrangements were by no means as good as they might have been and the sting and zest was absent from proceedings. Met Jack afterwards and we promenaded up to the University de Travail. Streets full of people and shops are getting bright & well stocked. After some cakes and chocolate we walked home. Went to bed but was 

 

5/4/19

Marcinelle

soon pulled out by Miles and Harold Smith with news that little Georgie Hughes, Freddy Howell, Jackie Cowan and young Binns were all in the A.P.M’s clink at the Charleroi barracks! Quelle affaire! I went up with Gorman and “Scotty" the 24th RSM and found it only too true. Interviewed the A.P.M and got his leave to see them. The doctor & myself had no hesitation in pronouncing them all quite sober but (unofficially) Freddy & Georgie were really very drunk – so much so that I decided that they must stay in the place all night. So we left them there in a dark room under lock & key with one lone wraith of the 42nd Division floating round in his white riding breeches & chamois waistcoat like a nocturnal spectre!
Entry.27:
Marcinelle

Sent up to get the boys out of clink. Busy with preparations for the draft the young devils are going on. Put in worrying day about them and eventually had to warn other officers for draft in their room. Late in the evening I had to give Fraser about 3 hours notice to go. Took supper with the Mathys’.
Entry.28:
Up at 6 and saw our draft off. Spoke to the men before moving and expressed thanks to them. Then with bands playing and flags flying the draft moved off and looked very well. At the station met General Tivey and he spoke to the men before entrainment started. Walked along the train shaking hands with various ones till at last it steamed off the band playing Auld Lang Syne. Took a 

 

7/4/19

Marcinelle

Ford car down to H.Q. 2nd M.F.Coy and there met General Cam Stewart with whom I sat as member of a G.C.M on an officer charged with stealing Govt. goods cycles etc. Brought Col. St Clair home to lunch and then returned to the same place where we sentenced our friend. Returned and had a short rest before dinner engaged on matters of routine. After dinner Selleck proceeded to take a Summary of Evidence in the case of Cowan & Coy. A.P.Ms and all sorts of other people came too. I spoke my bit at about 11 p.m.
Entry.29:
A busy morning. Heard several Orderly Room cases and awarded punishments. A fine sunny day. Our mess very funny with silence – the naughty Jacky, Freddy & Geo. now very quiet.

 

8/4/19

Marcinelle

At 6 pm Colonel Davis called with sidecar and took me over to Marchienne au Pont where we went to a café and sat down at a table – full was the café. The waitress solemnly brought us our coffee cups full – of whisky and we as solemnly sipped it. There is much traffic going on between civilians and canteens. Men buy and resell. Went to Dr Hiernaux’s and spent a pleasant evening. Alix will be fat later and is petite. The Madame laughs insincerely. Drank wine talked and had some music. Tasted here mint tea for the first time. Left about 10.30 and had a quiet run home – a fine mild night. Read for a while before going to bed.
Entry.30:
Marcinelle

Went to see General Martin & had long discussion there re Mont St Quentin memorial with Col. Chalmers & Major McCall. After met Cols. Forbes and Davis at Bde H.Q. and discussed demobilization questions with the Staff. In early afternoon walked round Charleroi – the pleasant day made this enjoyable. Barges marked Ghent Rotterdam and Antwerp on the canal and the usual curious crowd watching the locks at work. At 4.30 took afternoon tea with Dr Mathys and ate gauves. Then took them to see the 5th Bde Concert party who were very good but too much for the Mathys to understand. The “girl" of this party is very good and makes up splendidly. Put all our bad eggs into Charleroi barracks today where they get rough treatment.
Entry.31:
Marcinelle

Fairly quiet morning fixing up small matters. At 2.30 paraded Freddy & Co. round to General Tivey. In the presence of Genl. Martin he gave them a good rating and they all then went home. Bill May came over during the afternoon and had some afternoon tea. Word of further drafts 14th 21st and 28th. Ellwood goes on leave to the Rhine tomorrow. At mess of an evening now we get about 15 officers all round one table – a change to other times when 30 to 40 would at one time sit down to dinner. The bonne at this house is a perfect slave going day and night. No wonder many prefer the streets to this kind of economic slavery. Took a tour round the Old Town before dark – days are longer now.
Entry.32:
Marcinelle

Took a couple of Orderly Rooms and saw Staff Capt Hale about getting rid of our Transport. Met Father Campbell and there passed a car containing R.C. bishop who got out very gorgeous in a purple cassock and tiny surplice. Had a good bath at the Railway station about 2.30. After evening mess went to the Concordia Hall to see the “Smart Set" 4th Divnl. Concert Party. They were very good indeed and gave a fine programme but their “girl" is not as good as the one in the 5th Bde. Party. The hall is a Catholic institution. Home about 9 just in time to see the Cinema coming out. Orders for 167 people to go on draft on the 21st – put in some time picking them and so to bed.
Entry.33:
Marcinelle

Tried a couple of Orderly Room cases. One McCormack of 23rd came before me handcuffed and was remanded for Court Martial. There is a lot of traffic now in military stores and the canal bank in front of the station is the mart after dark and known as Rue de Combien. Saw General Martin afternoon and arranged several matters with him. Afternoon tea in the mess and then a walk round the Charleroi streets to buy a couple of papers. After mess went to Pictures at the Cinema Hall – very poor show and a great barrage of tobacco smoke. Took another walk up the street. The mildness of Spring is in the air and the buds are green and bursting. Filthily casual in their habits of sanitation are the Belgians.
Entry.34:
Marcinelle

Church parade at 10.30 a.m. was poorly attended and a wretched farce. The officers & men only go under compulsion & we find that voluntary parades fail. At 1.30 a draft of 70 men paraded in the Square to be seen off by me. I spoke the usual few words and then Band at head they marched off to report at the Divisional Reinf. Wing. In the evening went to “La Traviata" with Gorman – a fairly good show but weak orchestra & a bad mannered audience. Entre actes the usual mingling of the sexes insanitarily. To Café Central full of officers and some evil looking ugly girls dancing. Prostitution in an ugly industrial town like Charleroi is a nakedly ugly thing.
Entry.35:
Marcinelle

Up betimes and to the Station to see off a small draft of about 60 all told and including Charlie Hutton. Generals Hobbs Tivey and Martin were all down at the station. Travelling is done in German trucks marked “Stettin" “Breslau" etc and all comforts and other gear is put aboard by Hun prisoners. Such is the irony of War! At 9.30 the trains teamed out somewhat rapidly and it took a lot of scrambling before the troops got aboard. Farewells were exchanged from the moving trucks and one chap passing a group of Hun prisoners called out “Au Revoir, Fritz, you bastard!" in cheerful pleasantry. Met Colonel Forbes later in the morning and with him saw General Martin about several matters. Lunched and then

 

14/4/19

Marcinelle

took a walk up the street looking at the shops & killing time till afternoon tea hour. It came on to rain heavily in the late afternoon – a steady growing rain. The heavy green buds of the trees only want this to make them burst. In the evening had dinner with the Mathys and Jamsins. An exquisite dinner. The Belgians are rather angry with England for supporting Geneva as the seat of the League of Nations. Madame Mathys was a little disappointed at not being asked by us to come to “La Traviata". The wine very good 6 bottles to 5 persons the doctor says is his measure of Burgoyne. Very tasty. A finale of coffee and Benedictine sent everyone home just pleasantly elated. They speak of parties of 3 who can polish off 15 bottles.
Entry.36:
Marcinelle

Took a walk up towards the Waxworks but did not go in. An attempt was made to steal our horses last night but failed and I tried a foolish looking chap of the 17th Battalion & remanded him for Court Martial. From the Cavalry Barracks last night twelve birds escaped. In days past this never happened – now corruption is rife. 

At midday went up to the Waxworks and had a look at the horrors there. Took afternoon tea at the mess having first wandered out and done some shopping. A windy thundery and showery day. Spent the evening with the Cornils.
Entry.37:
Marcinelle

An unexciting day at the close of which I went to the Peter’s house and heard them curse the and their party.
Entry.38: Swiss leave said to be thro! Saw the General and arranged to get away tomorrow provided the pass turns up. Had 4 o’c tea with the Mathys and arranged to go the Fille de Regiment and Noces de Jeanette with them this evening. Ate many gouves with coffee and custard. Went to Varieties with Madame and the doctor and there saw an act of Les Noces de Jeanette and La Traviata. The latter was put on instead of La Fille de Regiment owing to an actor having failed to turn up. The chief singer here was once the principal of Amsterdam. The performance on the whole was fair to medium. Found no pass for leave.
Entry.39:
Marcinelle

Up very early and had breakfast. A lovely mild Spring day it would have been ideal for commencing a leave. C’est dommage que le passport n’arrive pas! Went down to D.H.Q at 10 a.m. and saw Roberts who rang up Corps who said my leave had been passed. He had the authority and it said that passports had to be gotten in Paris so must needs go there. The R.T.O rung up says next train 9 pm tonight. Visited station later on and got concession ticket at 10 fr but no couchettes. Went to the M.P.’s and found that bribery would get a bunk for 40 francs – not worth it but requested M.P. to try and reserve a seat. A lovely warm sunny afternoon. After mess went up the street and had a shave. Remarkable how scrupulously clean these

 

18/4/19

Marcinelle

people are about their houses. They scrub the outside front walls and lintels daily with soap and water and the scrubbing of the flags is an event of two or three times a day. Their care in this respect is a marked contrast to their filthy lack of sanitation and their dislike to washing their bodies. On the canal this warm pleasant evening are many barges and the watermen and their wives sit yarning. Got away from Charleroi station at about 9 pm on a packed train. The journey all night was one of the most wretched I ever remember. Had to sit on my suitcase crouched up against the heater of a wagon lit. All night had no sleep – there were women (some elderly) crouched in the corridors.
Entry.40:
Paris

Reached Paris at 7.40 a.m. and took a taxi to the Continental where I got a room. Then tore off to the British Embassy after passport had the devil’s own job getting it, tore down to Prefecture of Police in a taxi and could not get a visa. Went then to Swiss consulate and they definitely refused me leave to go there. The Champs Elysees were looking lovely this morning all the trees out in bloom and a light sunny blue haze hanging round the Arc de Triomphe. Wonderful the number of really beautiful women and girls of all ages one sees here. Walked round all the old familiar streets this afternoon some of the boulevards are a lovely blush of green. Then went down to the Luxembourg Gardens all full of kids. And so home by tube feeling tired. Went for

 

19/4/19

Paris

Dinner to Arrigonis and along the crowded boulevards for a while. Gay crowds in all the cafes. To Folies Bergeres and got into the promenade – a poor show but rather good stage effects. Girls wear nothing on their backs above their waists and only two narrow bands in front.
Entry.41:
Paris

Did not wake up until ¼ to 10. Had a hot bath dressed in mufti and walked through Place Vendome to Opera and then along to Madeline. A great crowd was going in and out the old churches and an American was taking bioscope pictures of it. Went in and found a great mass being celebrated this Easter Sunday. The music was exquisite both vocal and instrumental. The crowd was like an Opera audience. The old cocked hat sacristans are well known identities here. Tubed to Gare de L’Est and booked through to Strassburg tonight. There was a little excitement on one of the platforms between a man & a woman. Came back to Opera and walked along Bde. des Italiens to an Italian café (Poccardis?) opposite Arrigonis. Lunched here and then made for the Louvre

 

20/4/19

Paris

expressly to see the Venus de Milo. She was not there when I had previously visited the place. This celebrated statue is impressive. Wandered round the Galleries and then came out into the Tuilleries near the Arc de Caroussel. From here there is a prospect that cannot be equalled anyway. All round are gardens & statues & the long wings of the mighty Louvre. The green trees of the Tuilleries garden continue till the Concorde obelisk coming into view – then the green of the Champs Elysees and further on straight ahead the Arc de Triomphe. On the left is the Eiffel Tower and on the right the essentially French architecture of the shops and arcades of Rue de Rivoli. There are a number of wooden in the Tuilleries in preparation for a fair. Bought a few things

 

20/4/19

Paris

before returning to hotel to pack up. With about 5000 a year Paris would be a delight – the home of the wealthy. Rested and read until about 6.30 p.m. and then paid my bill and got myself and baggage put on a taxi for the Gare de L’Est. Took what will probably be the last look for a long time at the Opera and all the other old familiar places. Reached Gare de L’Est and got a place for Strassbourg. The carriage of this train (and many others now) was German and bore the Imperial arms. On French lines there now seems to be abundance of Hun material. The carriage splendidly comfortable and each passenger has much more sitting space than other nations seem to give. Latrine & other arrangements all seem good. Each “place" gives ample room only 2 on each side of the carriage. 2 French Majors & A.F.C. Lt. as companions.
Entry.42:
Strasburg

Not a bad night – slept sitting up travelling all the time. Dawn found us going through Alsace Lorraine and we passed some old trenches much barbed wire and some ruined villages. At last we got into the Vosges and mountainous pretty country with heavy woods. Glimpses of streams and wooded valleys. Ran out into open land and made Strassbourg about 9 a.m. A porter took me to Hotel du Poste a cheap lodging. This is Easter Monday and all the shops are closed. Walked up the street as far as Place Kleber where there is a statue to the General of that name who was killed at Cairo. From here to Cathedral a fine building on whose tower flies a tricolour. Entered and found a service in progress some good stained 

 

21/4/19

Easter Monday. Strassburg

glass. Bought a couple of tickets and climbed the tower. A fine sunny day but strong wind made the tower seem rocky & cold. Narrow stairs and open sides – one could easily get giddy and fall over. From the tower a splendid view and one realises that the town has many very old houses. The various churches and squares show up plainly from this great height and then all round are open fields. The Rhine runs about 2 kilos away and high mountains in distance are Vosges and Jura. A ground haze was hanging but I thought I could distinguish the Black Forest. Descended to the street and went in to see the celebrated Clock of Strassburg which is in a sort of side chapel. It is a wonderful affair
